Sure was a long wait (again!) but well worth it! The jet-fueled premier of the 4th run was incredibly satisfying in itself, and promises much more over the next several weeks -- like tying up at least some of the purposely left loose ends from the preceding seasons as well adding new twists.
Katey Sagal is as fierce & fabulous as ever; didn't think it was possible, but the ensemble cast seems even more relaxed & enmeshed than before, very believable that they have known each other for ages, thru all kinds of stormy weather. A consistent show strength has been to demonstrate the cohesiveness of the club while illustrating the concerns, doubts, resentments that flicker thru & between individual members or associates -- these actors all seem to have a gift for nuance, and the camera work complements it well.
My experience has been that at least 2 viewings are required to even begin to pick up all the glances and grimaces that further the story, not to mention verbal & visual allusions. For instance, I noticed that the Asst. U.S. Attorney has pictures of Otto & Juice under the heading "Plan B" on his office wall of shame (mug shots & photos of Samcro and everyone living or dead ever associated w/ the club). So the 2nd time I watched Juice more closely (and what I saw makes me kinda nervous...and very anxious for the next episode!)

In season 4, the producers decided to add a "previously on SOA" reel as a lead in to each episode.  This is a really bad addition that ruins the flow if you're watching a whole season in a few sittings.  With a series made for TV being released on disc, all of that kind of thing should be deleted, the opening credits, the theme song, and this review of earlier scene snips.

  It's easy to see how HBO just shouldered network TV aside when they started producing serial sagas with each episode running an hour or more and the format improvement of no commercial breaks.  SOA, Justified and TWD would all have been much better if they had been made by HBO.  The old, hidebound TV networks can't die off soon enough.  That they have produced a few series offerings that rose a little above their usual old boring stuff won't save them.

Even if the police are somewhat under your power.  There have been quite a few episodes where I found myself saying, "oh, come on!" or "yeah, right!"  Also, the show borders on being a soap opera at times, but then again, so did other better series, like the Sopranos or Mad Men.  But we still binge watch it at times and it's definitely a lot of fun, especially once you get to know some of the characters well.  If you can suspend your disbelief for a while you will thoroughly enjoy S.O.A.

The thing about SoA is that while it is entertaining and ovrall, the acting is good, there is always this underlying feel that it is just another soap opera.  Nothing about the way these people react to situations in their lives mirrors real life.  Are there biker gangs up to no good in the world?  Probably.  There are certainly biker gangs who do a lot of good things too.  But I started watching this show and it was a brotherhood of men who often came back from theaters of war and needed to belong to something.  Now, they are international gun runners, drug dealers for the CIA, family killing family, and somewhere on the horizon, I can see Fonzi on his motorcycle getting ready to jump the shark tank.  I feel like whenever they think the show is losing steam, they take it to such an extreme that it loses any sense of authenticity it may have had.  More brutality and death doesn't a good show make.  I have actually stopped watching SoA because of the brutality and I find it incredibly depressing.

I have to admit I have been hooked by SOA from the very first episode.  As the first several seasons developed, I began feeling like the show was turning into a soap opera dressed in leathers.  The plot lines revolved around who's screwing who, who's back-stabbing who, who's lying to who... but ultimately, that didn't matter, I eagerly awaited each show.

I love the fact that the backstory is based on Hamlet.  That Jax is playing the part of Hamlet, Clay is Uncle Claudius, Jenna is Hamlet's mother Gertrude and JT is the ghost of Hamlet's murdered father.  You could even find parallels between Jax's best friend Opie and Hamlet's good friend Horatio.  About the only one that doesn't fit the scheme is Jax's girl Tara.  She's certainly no Ophelia, that is unless the writers intend on having her go mad and commit suicide.  Still, I like the way the writers have based the story on one of Shakespeare's greatest tragedies. It lends a story a level of class and sophistication that I wouldn't expect in a show about bikers.

Another thing I like about the show is its sense of balance.  It's got everything; action, adventure, romance, intrigue, humor, it really has it all.  One week you're watching the Sons shoot it out with the Mayans, and the next week the show has me in practically in tears as Tig mistakenly kills Opie's wife Donna.

Can't say enough about the acting.  There are no slouches in this cast.  Jax, Jenna and Clay are all superb.  I've even learned to appreciate the minor characters like the sheriff Wayne Unser.  He does an excellent job, as do the other supporting players like Bobby Elvis, Juice, Chibs and Opie.  Too, villans like Agent Stahl and U.S. Attorney Lincoln Potter are extremely well played and multi-dimensional.

"Sons Of Anarchy: Season Four"
NOTE: Mild spoilers below. Don't freak out.

On its own, this season of SOA would probably get a 4-star rating: the first few episodes were hard to get into and the entire subplot about Juice being afraid of being "outed" as an African-American simply didn't ring true: the Sons spent their first two seasons combating the local white supremacist gang, and had expressed a dislike of their ideology. Now, suddenly, they're all racist themselves and Juice is so flipped out about it that he's willing to rat them out to the Feds? Sorry -- I don't buy it. It was way too forced and didn't serve that great a dramatic purpose. Meanwhile, Jax is still wringing his hands about what to do with his life and is still spinning around in the same should-I-stay-or-should-I-go? circles he's been running in for the entire show.  I know this is meant to be a Hamlet parallel, but it's starting to wear thin.  Also, the new Top Cop character was a little too "quirky" for my tastes. Still, by the time the second half of the season rolled around, we were transfixed, and wanted to see what was going to happen next. The last couple of episodes were sharp enough to make us eager to see what happens next.

The reason I'm giving the show a 1-star rating, though, is as a protest vote against Amazon's new monopolistic sales policies, in which they are colluding with HBO, Fox and other companies to forbid Amazon customers from reselling their DVDs on Amazon: you can buy "Sons Of Anarchy" on Amazon, but if you try to sell it used, suddenly it's a "restricted item" and they won't let you. What's worse is they will allow *some* Amazon-affiliated sellers to provide it used, but not regular folks like you and me. The idea is, apparently, to crack down on bootlegs as well as artificially boost the used prices and, I would imagine, to push more customers towards Amazon's vastly inferior download and streaming video services, so that the video companies don't "lose" more money through re-sales. Well, since I bought this show brand new, directly from Amazon, I don't think it's a bootleg, and I think that I should be able to resell it there as well, as I've always been able to before. Now, if Amazon wanted to stop ALL used sales on their site altogether, that would be one thing, but playing favorites with "pre-approved" sellers seems pretty unfair and smells a bit like monopoly practices to me. Just one more reason to migrate away from Amazon's sphere of influence, I guess. I really don't like the high-handed way Amazon is treating its customers these days. (Axton)
